title: PACE: Idea collaboration tool
description: Quality proposals require ideas which have had sufficient thought, feedback and the right team to execute

f6_assessments.q0: Good idea, but the question that has to be asked is would this not be better handled just by opening up Ideascale earlier to allow early versions of proposal to be submitted and commented upon?
f6_assessments.q1: The team has the ability to deliver this proposal. The budget is relatively generic, with the same format as a number of others by the same proposer.  What exactly is the software that will be used to deliver this (for the cost its not going to be written from scratch)?. The biggest part not really defined however is how to integrate it into the community. How do we get people to spend time proposing and commenting on proposal outside the current process. Also will there be a simple system to automatically port ideas across to ideascale for submission and keep track of ideas and teams across the two platforms.
f6_assessments.q2: A reasonable simple plan in terms of deliverables makes that side easy to audit. However success should really be linked to the number of idea submitted to it, ideations and iteration of these, community members involved, and most importantly, the number of polished proposals which come out of it are submitted to idea scale and are then funded.

f6_assessments.q0: The proposal doesn't fit the challenge. It won't help entrepreneurs to develop their skills to execute & communicate great ideas so voters/stakeholders value the project. I would advise you to consider submitting it into another category. In general it looks to be just a costly tool on top of Ideascale and there is no clarity how the tool will look like.
f6_assessments.q1: While the proposal is long enough, it looks to be copy-pasted from another set of proposals made by the same team. There is very small information on the tool itself and how it will look like and will function, but a lot of general information not related to the particular proposal
f6_assessments.q2: The budget is not detailed and key metrics are not indicated. It is not clear how exactly this tool will work and will people use it, and if they will use it, how to track this usage.

f6_assessments.q0: Nicely described proposal with clear view how the proposer addresses the problem. I also think that the proposal impact is also high since it provides a better chance to submit ideas outside of the given time frame and debate them openly. It would be good it a comparison breakdown could be made between the existing solution and the tool to clearly see what it brings and answers why it would be better than e.g. opening such a topic in discord.
f6_assessments.q1: The proposer clearly describes the experience, work packages and shares details about the exact developers which is also rarity.
f6_assessments.q2: Time and budget breakdown is available in the proposal and they are measurable. Therefore, the proposal is clearly auditable.

f6_assessments.q0:
This proposal provides a means by which ideas can be shared to get feedback or to find potential collaborators. The end result being a better idea. Its a good idea however it does not address the challenge which is to develop entrepreneur's skills to execute and communicate great ideas. The challenge assumes that the entrepreneur already has a "great idea".
Based upon my experience, I neither agree nor disagree that this proposal effectively addresses the challenge.
f6_assessments.q1:
The proposers provide ample evidence of relevant skills. Budget, timeline and plan are all good. The proposal highlights the challenge of marketing the product as requirement for its effectiveness and provides a plan to address.
Based upon my experience, I strongly agree that it is highly likely that this proposal will be implemented successfully
f6_assessments.q2:
The proposal provides a roadmap with auditable milestones and a defined timeline plus well defined metrics. Milestones in the roadmap should be more definite and not tse the words "should" and "may". Open source code in a github repository with weekly project updates provides a complete auditing package.
Based upon my experience, I strongly agree that this proposal provides me with sufficient information to assess the progress in attaining its stated goals.

f6_assessments.q0: I strongly agree that this proposal effectively addresses the challenge. It brings a solution to strengthening the quality of proposals via the creation and use of an idea collaboration tool in Catalyst, one that is open to participants at all times and not only during the Insight sharing face (which is open for 1 week). This gives the proposers ample time to prepare for upcoming funds, and collaborate and communicate freely within their own timeframe, but within the Catalyst platform. From my understanding it is not meant to replace the Insight sharing phase, but rather complement it with a more free, less time constricting option. The solution correlates strongly with both the problem statement and the challenge brief in this regard. The possibility of increasing the quality of proposals is a decent investment in the catalyst ecosystem, that will (In time) benefit proposers, voters and community advisors.
f6_assessments.q1:
The team standing behind the proposal have more than sufficient experience working with the tasks required to launch this tool. They are deeply involved in and seems to have deep understanding of Ideascale and the Project Catalyst, and also have experience of having previous proposals funded in Fund5. Information and links to their LinkedIn pages and partnerships are provided in order for community members to verify their credibility. 
A detailed budget including labour hours and time allocation is provided in a reasonable and clear way, with few opportunities for misunderstanding. The proposal also includes understanding of what aspects of the process will be most imperative (marketing) or present potential challenges. 
Since the idea collaborator tool is promised to be ready for launch immediately (with a 5 week monitoring, marketing and development period presented as part of the roadmap), I strongly agree that it is highly likely that this proposal will be implemented successfully.
f6_assessments.q2:
The proposal features a short but clear roadmap spanning over 12 months, with milestones included. Having a slightly more detailed description of the success metrics would increase the quality of the report. It could for example be 'What quantity of ideas in circulation are we expecting to achieve by x point in time?', or 'How many users do we expect/want to register by x months?' 
The community is available to easily audit the process and development of the project with the inclusion of weekly development updates, a GitHub link connected to their previously funded proposals, and using open source code in their development. I would have liked to see a section of the proposal that describes potential challenges and risks in a reasonable and clear way, and how the project means to adress these. It could be in regards to the marketing challenge, as mentioned before. 
All in all, I strongly agree that this proposal provides me with sufficient information to assess the progress in attaining the stated goals.

f6_assessments.q0: It's an excellent idea that addresses an area that's a bit ignored in this challenge – i.e. the longterm build-up, problem-sensing and teambuilding that underpins an effective proposal. It addresses entrepreneurs "building their skills" via peer support and team building (rather than focusing on individuals building their skills in isolation), which is really appropriate for a  distributed, open community like Catalyst.
f6_assessments.q1:
Agree, with one reservation.
The team clearly have a good track record in building community tools on time and within budget; and their budget and timescale look workable. 
But they (correctly, I think) say "Marketing will be the most important factor for this proposal" – and yet their team doesn't include anyone with skills in marketing or community engagement. These are **real skills**, not just something anyone can do; and especially when it's identified as the main factor in a project's success, some skilled and experienced input would be beneficial. For a project like this,  community engagement skills would be appropriate, rather than straight-up marketing. As it stands, the proposers say the tool will mainly be marketed by them interacting directly with community members they think might be interested; so there's a danger that the promotion might be too focused on their existing personal networks. With the challenge's aim to "help an increasingly diverse group of Project Catalyst entrepreneurs" it's important that a proposal like this has a plan for how to reach out widely, perhaps especially to those who are new, or in some way marginalised, or not very well connected. In fact, these kinds of people are probably the tool's main targets, since people who are already well connected across the whole of Catalyst are already doing this type of ideas-development in their existing personal networks.

In short, the creation of the tool is very feasible, but it needs more thought and expertise to ensure that those who need it most feel "invited". Still – it looks like the team might have access to some of that expertise via their links with LidoNation?

And a small point - total time allocation only adds up to 90%...   :-) If 10% is "contingency", best to say so clearly...
f6_assessments.q2:
The metrics suggested are good, measurable, and it's great that they don't stop at simply showing that the tool is being used, but extend to showing that its use is having positive effects. Also, it's great that not all the metrics suggested are about creating  proposals – there are also ways to measure wider community benefits such as  increased interaction, discussion, teambuilding etc.. And very good that the tool itself is open source and readily auditable via Github. So yes, there's clearly enough info to audit both progress and success.
One suggestion – it would be good to try to also measure whether the tool increases the quality of proposals. Hard to prove, admittedly – but maybe something like the average CA score of proposals developed out of this tool, vs the average across the board?

solution: Provide a tool for the community to get feedback on ideas at anytime outside the funding process and allow teams to form more easily
experience: 5 years of web/mobile development experience, 1 year of strategic consulting experience, funded for Catalyst focussed proposals in fund 5
